summary: This document appears to be a news article or opinion piece discussing Jeffrey Epstein's legal situation in 2006, including his indictment on a felony charge of solicitation of prostitution and civil lawsuits alleging sexual exploitation of teenage girls. It criticizes Epstein's use of high-profile attorneys and his efforts to avoid prosecution.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Manhattan money manager indicted on one felony charge of solicitation of prostitution in July 2006; facing civil lawsuits alleging sexual exploitation of underage girls.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Harvard Law School Professor and member of Epstein's large legal defense team.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Former independent counsel and member of Epstein's legal defense team.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: West Palm Beach attorney on Epstein's legal team who commented on the case to a Post columnist.

persons.name: Jose Lambiet
persons.context: Post columnist who interviewed Jack Goldberger about the Epstein case in November.

persons.name: Lilly Ann Sanchez
persons.context: Epstein attorney who dismissed allegations, stating "Jeffrey Epstein did not have sex with this woman."

persons.name: Robert Gates
persons.context: Defense Secretary who acknowledged comments on troop levels in a different context within the document.

persons.name: Gen. Franks
persons.context: Mentioned in the opening paragraph regarding military matters in 2003, unrelated to Epstein.

connections.description: Dershowitz is part of Epstein's large legal defense team.
Starr is part of Epstein's large legal defense team.
Goldberger is an attorney on Epstein's payroll and part of his legal team.
Sanchez is an attorney representing Epstein and dismissing allegations against him.
Goldberger gave an interview about the Epstein case to columnist Jose Lambiet.

events.title: Epstein Indictment
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was indicted on one felony charge of solicitation of prostitution after an 11-month police investigation.

events.title: Alleged Abuse Incident
events.description: According to a lawsuit, Epstein allegedly masturbated in front of a 14-year-old girl and used a vibrator on her at his home.

events.title: Lawsuit Filed
events.description: A civil lawsuit seeking more than $50 million was filed against Epstein, alleging sexual exploitation of a teenage girl.

events.title: Goldberger Interview
events.description: Attorney Jack Goldberger told columnist Jose Lambiet that the Epstein case would end without a trial within two months.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was indicted in July 2006 on one felony charge of solicitation of prostitution after an 11-month police investigation.
Civil lawsuits allege Epstein sexually exploited teenage girls, with one incident described occurring in February 2005 involving a 14-year-old.
Epstein retained a high-profile legal team including Alan Dershowitz, Kenneth Starr, Jack Goldberger, and Lilly Ann Sanchez.
Police searches of Epstein's home and garbage found phone information about girls' school schedules and a high school transcript.
Epstein's defense reportedly included claims that he did not know the ages of the girls and that the lawsuits were about money.
